LICENSING REQUIREMENTS

To protect the general public, Alabama law created the Alabama Real Estate
Commission to license and regulate real estate professionals. For AREC to
accomplish this goal, Alabama license law specifies which activities require a
license and how to obtain a license.
Activities requiring
a license Alabama law requires any person, sole proprietorship, partnership, corporation,
branch office, or legal business organization engaging in the practice of real
estate for compensation to be licensed as a real estate broker or salesperson. The
license must also be on active status to perform such activity.
Compensation includes fees, commissions, or other valuable consideration
received from another person in exchange for performing certain activities.
Performing licensed activities with the intention or expectation of receiving
compensation is considered the same as actually receiving compensation for
purposes of defining whether a license is required.
Engaging in the practice of real estate includes:
 offering or selling, exchanging, purchasing, renting, or leasing real
estate located in Alabama
 negotiating the listing, sale, exchange, purchase, rental, or leasing
of real estate located in Alabama
 listing for sale, rental, lease, exchange, or trade any real estate
located in Alabama
 auctioning any real estate located in Alabama
 optioning real estate located in Alabama
 locating for purchase, rent, or lease any real estate located in
Alabama
442 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

 procuring prospects for the purpose of selling, exchanging, leasing,
or renting of any real estate located in Alabama
 presenting oneself as being able to perform any act for which a
license is required
Again, engaging in any of these activities for compensation within the State of
Alabama requires an active Alabama real estate license.
Qualifications for
a salesperson's
license Alabama requires that the license for a broker or salesperson be registered to a
specific real estate office. The license will be issued and held only by a person
who meets all of the following requirements.
Personal requirements. All license applicants must be trustworthy and
competent to transact real estate business in a way that safeguards public interest.
The applicant must also meet the following requirements:
 at least 19 years old
 U.S. citizen or legally present in the U.S. with the appropriate
documentation from the U.S. government or an alien with
permanent U.S. resident status
 resident of any state in the U.S.
 no rejection or revocation of an application or license in any state
within 2 years prior to the Alabama application date on any grounds
other than failure to pass the written examination; applicants whose
license has been revoked must meet all requirements for an original
license and must be approved by the AREC
Nonresident applicants. If the applicant is a nonresident of Alabama and does
not hold a current license in another state but wishes to practice real estate in
Alabama, he or she must apply for a salesperson's license.
This nonresident applicant must show proof of all of the following:
 high school graduate or the equivalent
 successful completion of 60 hours of AREC approved real estate
coursework
 any other information the Commission requires
If the applicant is a nonresident and holds a current license in another state, even
if he or she becomes an Alabama resident, the individual must apply for a
reciprocal salesperson license in Alabama. (Reciprocal license requirements and
application procedures are covered in detail later in this chapter.)
Chapter 26: Alabama Licensing Regulation 443

Any nonresident applicant for an Alabama original license or for a reciprocal
license must also sign an affidavit agreeing that
 AREC has jurisdiction over the applicant and his or her activities
 he or she will be subject to the same investigations and disciplinary
actions as Alabama resident licensees
 civil actions may be taken against him or her in any Alabama court
of competent jurisdiction
 the applicant appoints the AREC Executive Director or Assistant
Executive Director as his or her agent who will be served with any
disciplinary, judicial, or other legal notices
 any service upon his or her agent will be the same as service upon
him or herself
 certified copies of the appointment of agent will be sufficient
evidence just the same as the original appointment
 the appointment will be effective for as long as the applicant has
any liability remaining in Alabama
 the applicant is bound by all of the Alabama Real Estate License
Law just as if he or she were an Alabama resident
Criminal backgrounds and fingerprints. The AREC may reject the application
of anyone who has been convicted of or pleaded guilty or nolo contendere to a
felony or to a crime involving moral turpitude. If an applicant has such a
conviction or guilty plea, he or she may file an "Application for Determination of
Licensing Eligibility" form with the Commission. The Commission will review
the conviction and determine if the applicant is eligible for licensure in Alabama.
The AREC requires both state and national criminal history checks to be
performed on any applicant for licensure. The applicant must submit any required
information and fingerprints to the Commission, to the Federal Bureau of
Investigation, to the Alabama State Law Enforcement Agency or its successor, or
to a fingerprint processing service approved by the Commission.
Fingerprints are to be submitted on the approved fingerprint card. To avoid
having the application denied based on faulty fingerprints, the following steps
should be taken:
 fingerprints taken by an authorized official at a law enforcement
agency
 fingerprint card completely filled out at the top and signed by the
person being fingerprinted and the official who takes the
fingerprints
 fingerprint card containing only quality fingerprint impressions that
follow the examples given on the back of the card
 a properly executed application to review criminal history record
information submitted with the fingerprint card
 card examined by the official taking the fingerprints to ensure it is
filled out correctly and that the fingerprint impressions are adequate
444 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

The AREC may then use the criminal history to determine the qualifications and
fitness of the applicant to hold a real estate license. The applicant is responsible
for the cost of the criminal history check which must be current to the date of
license issuance.
These requirements are the same for both salesperson applicants and broker
applicants.
Education requirements. All applicants for licensure in Alabama must be a high
school graduate or the equivalent. Applicants must also complete the required
pre-license coursework.
Test requirements. In addition to all other requirements for qualifying for a
salesperson's license, each applicant for licensure must take and pass a written
examination. The Commission will either conduct the examination or contract
with an independent testing agency who will prepare, conduct, and grade the
examination. The fee for the examination will be set in the Commission's contract
with the independent testing agency.
Application and
documentation Documentation. All applicants for licensure in Alabama are required to submit
documentation in proof of age, citizenship or legal residency status, Alabama
residency, and high school graduation or equivalent. Alabama nonresidents
applying for a reciprocal license must submit proof of licensure in their resident
states.
The applicant may provide documentation in proof of age in the form of any of
the following:
 a valid driver's license
 a U.S. passport
 a birth certificate
 any other documentation the AREC deems acceptable
Applicants for licensure must also provide proof of U.S. citizenship, permanent
residency, or legal presence status. This proof may be submitted in the form of
any of the following:
 a driver's license
 a non-driver identification
 a U.S. birth certificate
 a permanent resident card (green card)
 a U.S. visa
 any other document issued by the U.S. indicating legal presence in
the United States
Proof of Alabama state residency can be submitted in the form of any of the
following:
 a driver's license
Chapter 26: Alabama Licensing Regulation 445

 a car tag receipt
 a deed to a home
 a lease agreement on a home or apartment
 a property tax bill
 a voter's registration card
 any other document the AREC deems acceptable
Nonresidents holding an Alabama license who become Alabama residents must
submit a change of address to the AREC within 10 days of residency, along with
any other license status changes.
Applicants must show one of the following as proof of meeting high school
completion requirements:
 high school diploma
 high school transcripts showing graduation date
 GED certificate
 College diploma
 College transcripts showing completion of at least two full terms
 DD-214 showing verification of high school completion
Applicants who were home schooled in the U.S. must provide a notarized
transcript and a letter of recommendation from the home school group leader.
Home school diplomas are not accepted.
Applicants who completed high school outside the U.S. must provide either of
the following:
 a transcript from a U.S. college showing sufficient high school
education for admittance into a college education program
 a Document-by-Document Evaluation Report verifying the foreign
education was equivalent to an American high school education
Temporary
licensure Temporary license education and test requirements. A person wishing to
conduct real estate business in Alabama is required to first obtain a temporary
license prior to completing post-license courses and obtaining an original
(permanent) salesperson license.
To obtain a temporary license, the individual must complete an approved 60-
hour pre-license course. The pre-license course must be completed within 1 year
from the start date or the student will not receive credit for the classes completed
and will need to start the course again. At least 80% of the course hours must be
presented by live instruction unless the course is an Association of Real Estate
License Law Officials (ARELLO) certified distance education course.
The student must then apply for and schedule the salesperson license state
examination. Applicants must pass the examination within 6 months after the
completion date of the pre-license course. Failure to meet the time frame
446 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

requirement will result in the applicant having to again complete the pre-license
course.
Temporary license application and issuance. Within 90 days after passing the
license examination, the applicant must find an Alabama-licensed qualifying
broker under whose supervision the salesperson applicant will work. The
qualifying broker must sign and submit a sworn statement of his or her belief of
the applicant's honesty, trustworthiness, and good reputation and of the broker's
willingness to accept responsibility for the salesperson's actions.
After passing the examination, securing the qualifying broker, and meeting all
other requirements for licensure, including paying the $30 Recovery Fund fee,
the applicant will be issued a temporary license certificate. The temporary
license is valid for 1 year.
Post-license education. During the 12 months of temporary licensure, the
salesperson must complete a 30-hour post-license course, apply for an original
salesperson license, and pay all associated application fees. The salesperson
should complete the post-license course and apply for the original license within
the first 6 months of temporary licensure. If the salesperson does not complete
the course within the first 6 months, the license will automatically be placed on
inactive status. The salesperson then has the remaining 6 months to complete the
course and apply for an original license. If the salesperson fails to complete the
post-license course within 12 months, the temporary license will automatically
expire and lapse. Temporary licenses may not be renewed.
Holding a temporary license is required for enrollment in the post-license
course. As with the pre-license course, a 90% attendance rate is required in live
instruction courses.
Original licensure Application process. After completing the post-license course, salespersons
holding a temporary license must apply for an original license on or before the
date the temporary license expires.
The salesperson must submit the original license application, appropriate fees,
and proof of completion of the post-license course to the Alabama Real Estate
Commission on or before midnight on the last day of the month 1 year from the
issuance of the temporary license.
For example, if Joe was issued a temporary license on April 4, 2027, he must
apply for his original license by midnight on April 30, 2028. Joe must also have
completed the post-license course and paid the license fee prior to that date and
time. However, keep in mind that Joe could obtain his original license sooner if
he completes the post-license course during the first 6 months he has his
temporary license. Otherwise, his temporary license will be placed on inactive
status after the first 6 months and will remain inactive until he completes the
coursework. If he doesn't complete the post-license course and apply for his
original license within the 12 months, his temporary license will lapse, and he
will have to start the entire process all over again.
Chapter 26: Alabama Licensing Regulation 447

Applicants who paid the Recovery Fund fee when applying for a temporary
license are not required to pay the fee again for original licensure. Therefore,
using the above example, if Joe paid the Recovery Fund fee when he applied for
his temporary license, he is not required to pay it again when he applies for his
original license.
License renewal All licenses, including inactive licenses, must be renewed to remain current. A
license may be renewed by filing an AREC license renewal form or by utilizing
the renewal option available at www.arec.alabama.gov. The licensee must also
pay a renewal fee and complete continuing education courses prior to renewal.
If the licensee is on active status, the Commission will mail the renewal form to
the licensee's place of business. If the licensee is on inactive status, the form will
be mailed to the licensee's residence. The Commission will mail the form prior to
August 1 of the final year of the license period. If the licensee does not receive
the form by August 1, he or she must notify the AREC by August 10. The form
may only be used for license renewal and not for any other reason, such as a
license transfer.
Renewal dates. The license period is 2 years, ending in even numbered years.
The license will expire at midnight on September 30 of the final year of the 2-
year license period. Renewals and renewal fees are due by August 31 of the final
year of the license period. Licenses renewed between September 1 and
September 30 will be charged a late renewal penalty in addition to the renewal
fee. Licenses not renewed by September 30 will expire and be placed on inactive
status on October 1.
Because the license period always ends in an even numbered year, the license
must be renewed in the next even numbered year, regardless of when it was
issued. For example, if the license was issued in April 2025, it would need to be
renewed in 2026, the next even numbered year. Similarly, if a license was
originally issued in April 2026, the license would need to be renewed that same
year because 2026 is an even numbered year.
Expired licenses may still be renewed during the 12 months following the
expiration date. If the license is not renewed during this 12-month period, the
license will lapse. The individual will then need to meet all the same
requirements of licensure applicable to individuals who have never been licensed
and reapply for licensure.
By not renewing the license by the September 30 deadline and then by allowing
the license to lapse after the 12-month renewal period, the individual will no
longer be considered a licensee and will no longer receive correspondence from
the AREC.
Under certain circumstances, the Commission may determine the existence of a
hardship for the licensee and allow an extended renewal date with payment of
renewal fees and penalties.
In addition to submitting the license renewal form and renewal fees, as well as
renewal penalties if applicable, the licensee must submit proof of completion of
approved continuing education courses.
448 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

Continuing education. Alabama licensees are required to complete 15 hours of
continuing education courses by September 30 of the final year of every 2-year
license period. If the licensee fails to meet this deadline, his or her license will be
placed on inactive status on October 1; and the licensee will be required to follow
all reactivation procedures. While on inactive status, the licensee will not be
allowed to perform any real estate activities that require a license.
Salesperson licensees fulfilling continuing education requirements may only take
approved courses from approved schools. To meet continuing education
requirements, the courses must include the following:
 Three Hours of “Risk Management: Initial Contact to Accepted
Offer.”
 12 hours of any AREC-approved courses, often referred to as
electives.
These courses must be "core" real estate courses and must assist the
licensee in fulfilling AREC's mission of protecting the public. Each
course must be at least 3 hours of instruction. The hours may
include such courses as
 license law
 RECAD (Real Estate Consumer’s Agency And Disclosure
Act)
 real estate ethics
 real estate financing
 appraisal and valuation
 fair housing
 truth-in-lending
 agency relationships
 agency disclosure
 liability of real estate agents
 writing contracts
 handling escrow funds
 environmental issues
 negotiating techniques
 listing and buyer presentations
 writing and presenting offers
 showing property
 sales skills
 communication skills
 marketing
 certain financial calculator courses
 computer courses which are real estate specific
 how to utilize technology in the practice of real estate
Chapter 26: Alabama Licensing Regulation 449

Examples of unacceptable subject matter include
 motivational courses
 personal development courses
 sales meetings
 in-house training
 orientation courses
Brokers and associate brokers must complete the required broker CE course and
9 hours of elective courses.
All course topics and content are subject to approval by the Commission.
The licensee must attend 100% of the course hours to be awarded continuing
education credit. If the licensee can provide proof of attendance, he or she does
not need to pass the courses to satisfy the requirements for renewal.
A licensee who completes an approved continuing education course in another
state may receive credit for the course in Alabama by submitting the appropriate
documentation to the Commission. Documentation must include verification of
course approval by the other state, the number of hours for which the course is
approved, and proof of course completion. Courses taken out of state will be
credited as elective courses only.
If the licensee completes more than the required 15 hours of course work, the
excess hours may not be carried over and applied to subsequent license period
requirements.
If the licensee serves as a member of the State Legislature during the license
period, that service can substitute for the 15 hours of course work for continuing
education.
A licensee who has been licensed for less than 1 year and is applying for first
time renewal is not required to complete the 15 hours of continuing education
course work for that renewal period. The licensee's post-license course counts as
continuing education credit for the first license period.
A reciprocal licensee who has held an Alabama license for less than 1 year is not
required to complete continuing education for the first renewal of his or her
license. This exemption only applies to reciprocal licensees who received an
Alabama license after September 30, 2015.
Exemptions from continuing education requirements. Alabama law allows for
two possible exemptions from the requirement to complete continuing education
before renewal:
450 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

 licensees who turn 65 years old on or before September 30, 2000,
and have been licensed for 10 years prior to that
 licensees on inactive status
Although inactive licensees are required to renew their licenses every 2 years,
this exemption means they do not need to complete continuing education courses
every license period while on inactive status. They will, however, be required to
complete the 15-hour continuing education requirement prior to reactivating their
licenses.
Reciprocal license If an individual holds a current real estate license in a qualifying state other than
Alabama, he or she may obtain a reciprocal license in Alabama. The license in
the other state must not be a reciprocal or non-resident license and must be on
either active or inactive status.
A qualifying state is one in which the applicant has completed pre-license course
work and passed an examination covering general (national) real estate and state
law for the state in which the examination was taken.
Applicants for a reciprocal license must provide a Certificate of Licensure issued
within the preceding 120 days from the state where the applicant is licensed. The
Certificate must show the following:
 the applicant's name and address,
 type of license,
 the license status over the previous 36 months,
 any record of disciplinary action, and
 the type of examination the applicant took and passed.
An applicant for a reciprocal license must also complete 6 hours of AREC-
approved course work in Alabama real estate and pass a written examination on
Alabama real estate with a score of 70% or higher. The applicant must pass the
examination within 6 months of completing the 6-hour course work. Failure to
meet this deadline will result in the applicant needing to complete the course
work again.
After completing the course work and passing the examination, the applicant
must then submit an application and the appropriate fees for a reciprocal license.
An applicant for a reciprocal license will pay the same licensure and Recovery
Fund fees as an Alabama license applicant.
Reciprocal license applicants who hold a salesperson license in the other state
must apply for a reciprocal salesperson license in Alabama, while applicants who
hold a broker license in the other state must apply for a reciprocal broker license
in Alabama.
After the reciprocal license is issued, the licensee must either complete Alabama-
required continuing education or show proof that his or her other state license is
still active.
Chapter 26: Alabama Licensing Regulation 451

Continuing education requirements for reciprocal licensees. Reciprocal
licensees have options regarding fulfilling continuing education requirements for
Alabama license renewal:
 the licensee may complete 15 hours of Alabama-approved
continuing education course work, including three hours of risk
management from initial contact to contract; the remaining 12
hours can be taken in another state if the licensee provides proof of
attendance in the courses, verification that the course was approved
by any real estate commission, and proof of the number of hours for
which the course was approved. Broker licensees must complete the
required broker CE course
 the licensee may submit a certification of licensure from the
regulatory agency in the state where the pre-license courses and
licensing examination were taken; the certification must include:
 type of license
 the current active status of the license
 the company that holds the license
 verification the pre-license course work requirements were
met in that state
 verification that a full state and national licensing
examination was passed in that state
 the certification must be dated no earlier than June 1 and
must be an original certification unless it is faxed to the
AREC
Co-brokering A principal broker who is licensed in a state other than Alabama may practice
real estate in Alabama if that broker signs a written agreement with a qualifying
broker licensed in Alabama. The agreement is called a co-brokerage agreement.
The agreement must specify each parcel of property the nonresident will be
handling, the financial terms of the agreement and any other material terms of the
agreement.
Prior to signing the agreement, the Alabama qualifying broker must confirm the
nonresident broker is licensed as a principal broker in the other state. A copy of
the agreement must be filed with the AREC within 10 days of execution.
The Alabama qualifying broker must require a listing or joint listing of any
property involved in the agreement. The Alabama qualifying broker must also
supervise any property showings and negotiations the nonresident broker
performs. Any advertising of Alabama real estate must include the name of the
Alabama qualifying broker.
All earnest money associated with transactions covered under the co-brokerage
agreement must be held in escrow by the Alabama qualifying broker unless both
the buyer and seller agree in writing to a different arrangement. The agreement
must specify all material terms, including financial terms. An out-of-state
452 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

principal broker who is working under a co-brokerage agreement is limited to
three real estate transactions totaling less than $50 million in sales each calendar
year. This limit would, however, allow transactions of multiple properties within
the same portfolio.
The Alabama qualifying broker is liable for the nonresident broker's actions
associated with the agreement as well as the Alabama qualifying broker's own
actions. However, by signing the co-brokerage agreement, the nonresident broker
agrees to abide by Alabama law and by the rules of the AREC. The co-broker
also agrees that civil action can be brought against him or her as a result of any
claims that may be filed in Alabama. If a complaint is filed against the out-of-
state principal broker, the regulatory body in that licensee’s home state will be
notified.
The Standard Interstate Co-Brokerage Agreement can be found on the AREC
website at AREC - Forms . Accessing it requires an online services login.
www.arec.alabama.gov/pages/forms.aspx
LICENSE STATUS

Broker and fee

Definition of an inactive license
Recovery fund fee exemption
Reactivation of an inactive license
Return of license
The status of an Alabama real estate license can be
 active: allows the licensee to legally practice the business of real
estate
 inactive: still valid but restricts the licensee from legally practicing
the business of real estate
 expired: not renewed prior to September 30 of the final year of the
license period; an expired license is on inactive status
 lapsed: not renewed within the 12 months following the expiration
date; a lapsed license may not be renewed or reactivated.
Definition of a
licensee Alabama law defines a licensee as any real estate broker, salesperson, or
company that is licensed as such under the requirements of Alabama license law.
Salespersons are licensed under and must work under the supervision of a
qualifying broker.
Brokers can be associate brokers or qualifying brokers.
Chapter 26: Alabama Licensing Regulation 453

A company is any sole proprietorship, corporation, partnership, branch office, or
lawfully constituted business organization which is licensed as a company under
Alabama license law.
A broker or salesperson's license is registered to a specific real estate office and is
issued to and held by a person who meets all of the requirements of Alabama
license law.
Transfer of license Although a salesperson or broker must be registered under a specific real estate
office and qualifying broker, the licensee may want to work for another
qualifying broker at some point in time. In this case, the licensee can transfer his
or her license to the other qualifying broker. To transfer, the licensee must give
notice of his or her intent to transfer in writing to the Commission and send a
copy of the notice to his or her current qualifying broker. The licensee must also
pay a $25 transfer fee.
The new qualifying broker must file a request for the transfer with the
Commission along with a statement assuming liability for the transferred
licensee.
A company or sole proprietorship wishing to change qualifying brokers must also
pay a license transfer fee for the license or licenses that contain the current and
the new qualifying broker's names. Companies with branch offices wishing to
change the qualifying broker for the main office will pay a license transfer fee for
each branch office license and each branch office qualifying broker's license.
When transferring to a new qualifying broker, the licensee must mail his or her
license by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the
Commission office along with the required transfer forms, license certificates,
and fee(s).
If the required forms and fees are submitted within 10 days after the Commission
receives the notice of transfer, the Commission will issue a new license
certificate to the licensee for the remainder of the current license term. The new
license certificate will be registered under the new qualifying broker.
If the necessary forms and fees are not submitted within the 10 days, the transfer
is null and void. The Commission will then return any submitted forms and fees
along with a notice to the licensee that the transfer was not complete.
If the transfer is not completed, the current qualifying broker remains responsible
for the licensee's actions.
Evidence of
transfer When the licensee mails the transfer documents and fee to the Commission, he or
she should keep the mail receipt as evidence of the license transfer. The date of
the mailing shown on the receipt will be the effective date of the transfer as long
as all of the necessary forms and fees were submitted by the required deadline.
Definition of an
inactive license An inactive license is one that restricts the licensee from performing any real
estate acts that require a license. Only an active license allows the licensee to
legally engage in real estate activities.
454 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

A license is inactive when
 being held by the AREC as a result of a legal action, an order of the
Commission, or at the request of the licensee
 the Commission issues it to inactive status at the licensee’s request
 it is still renewable but the licensee failed to renew it by the
deadline
 an individual with a temporary license does not complete the post-
license education requirements and apply for an original
(permanent) license within the first 6 months of temporary
licensure; in this case, the temporary license becomes inactive for
the second 6 months of temporary licensure.
Inactive licenses are held at the AREC office until they are activated. To engage
legally in real estate activities, the licensee must reactivate his or her license by
following the procedure outlined in Alabama license law and the AREC rules.
The procedure is explained below.
Recovery Fund
fee exemption A licensee is not required to pay a Real Estate Recovery Fund fee when his or her
license is issued on inactive status. However, the licensee must pay the fee before
he or she can activate the license. If the Commission charged a supplemental
Recovery Fund fee while the license was in inactive status, the licensee must also
pay that supplemental fee before activating the license.
Reactivation of
an inactive license Any licensee who wishes to reactivate his or her inactive license must apply to
the AREC for an activated license and pay the required fee(s). The fee(s) is
charged for each license being changed from inactive to active, but no fee is
charged for a license being changed from active to inactive.
In addition to applying for reactivation and paying the fee(s), the licensee must
also have completed the required 15 hours of continuing education for the current
license period prior to requesting reactivation. The licensee will be required to
complete an additional 15 hours of continuing education to qualify for license
renewal for the next license period.
For example, let's say that Jim's broker license has been on inactive status for 4
years. In April of the fourth year, Jim applies for reactivation. Jim must complete
15 hours of continuing education for the current 2-year license period that willl
end in the upcoming August. Then, by August 31 of that same year, Jim will also
need to complete an additional 15 hours of continuing education to renew his
license for the next 2-year license period.
Return of license If a corporation, partnership, or individually owned company wishes to stop a
broker or salesperson from doing business in its name, the entity can notify the
Commission and the broker or salesperson in writing and return the broker or
salesperson's license to the Commission.

LICENSING
REQUIREMENTS
Activities requiring a
license ● AREC regulates activities to protect the public
● real estate activities engaged in for compensation require an active license
● licensed activities include selling, buying, leasing, exchanging offering,
negotiating, listing, auctioning, or procuring real estate
● compensation includes fees, commissions, other valuable consideration, and the
intention of collecting a fee, commission, or other valuable consideration
Qualifications for a
salesperson's license ● at least 19 years old; U.S. citizen, alien with permanent resident status, or legally
present in U.S.; high school graduate or equivalent; pass written examination
● must show state of residence
● no license rejected or revoked within 2 years in any state
● nonresidents must apply for reciprocal license
● convictions of felony or crime involving moral turpitude may result in application
being rejected
● qualifications same for salespersons and brokers
Application and
documentation ● must provide documentary proof of age, U.S. citizenship, permanent residency, or
legal presence status, Alabama state residency, high school completion or home
schooling
● Alabama licensed nonresidents must submit change of address within 10 days of
becoming Alabama resident
Temporary license ● must obtain temporary license prior to post-license courses and permanent
salesperson license
● must complete 60-hour pre-license course within 1 year of start date with 80% of
hours live instruction unless ARELLO certified distance learning course and with
90% attendance rate; must pass course examination with 70% score
● must then pass written temporary licensure exam with score of 70% on both
national and state portions within 6 months of completing pre-license course;
failure to meet deadline results in retaking course
● must not engage in misconduct during examination or will be dismissed with score
not reported and fee not refunded
● within 90 days of passing exam, must find Alabama-licensed broker to work
under; qualifying broker to sign statement of applicant's honesty, trustworthiness,
and good reputation
● must pay $30 Recovery Fund Fee
● temporary license issued for 1 year to become inactive after 6 months for the
following 6 months
● salesperson to complete 30-hour post-license course during year of temporary
licensure, apply for permanent license, and pay all applicable fees; course may be
completed within first 6 months of temporary licensure to avoid inactive status
● temporary license will lapse and not be renewed if post-license course is not
completed by 1 year deadline
● all course assessment exams and final exam must be passed with score of 70%,
with 90% attendance rate in course

Original license ● after completing post-license course, salesperson must apply for
original/permanent license before temporary license lapses
● must submit license application, fees, and proof of post-license course completion
by end of year of temporary licensure
● if Recovery Fund Fee was paid with application for temporary license, salesperson
is not required to pay it again for original license
License renewal ● all licenses must be renewed to remain current, including inactive licenses
● licenses can be renewed by filing an AREC renewal form or online at AREC site
● the license renewal fee must be paid and continuing education requirements
completed prior to renewal
● AREC will mail renewal form to place of business for active licensees and to
place of residence for inactive licensees; form will be mailed prior to August 1 of
final year of license period; licensee must notify AREC by August 10 if form is
not received
● license period is 2 years, ending in even numbered years
● license expires at midnight September 30 of final year of license period
● renewal is due by August 31 of final year of license period
● renewals between September 1 and September 30 are charged renewal penalty
● renewals not completed by September 30 result in license placed on inactive status
● renewals not completed by September 30 can still be renewed during following 12
months after the expired/inactive status date
● renewals not completed during 12 months after inactive status result in license
lapsing and individual needing to meet all license application requirements again
● individuals wishing to cancel the license may simply non-renew and allow the
license to lapse
● AREC may extend renewal date for certain hardship circumstances
Continuing education ● licensees required to complete 15 hours of continuing education courses every
license period
● must be completed by September 30 of the final year of the license period
● failure to complete continuing education by deadline results in license being
placed on inactive status
● licensee may not perform real estate activities while on inactive status
● inactive licensees must renew their licenses but are not required to complete
continuing education until they reactivate their licenses
● licensees fulfilling continuing education requirements may only take approved
courses from approved schools
● courses must include 3 hours of Risk Management From Initial Contact to
Accepted Offer in any AREC approved course; all Level 2 courses must address
trust funds; 9 hours of AREC-approved core real estate elective courses
● all brokers must complete the 3 hour broker CE course
● some subject matter is unacceptable, such as motivational and personal
development courses or in-house training and sales meetings
● licensee must attend 100% of course hours
● continuing education courses may be taken in another state if AREC is notified;
out-of-state courses will be electives
● hours in excess of the required 15 are not credited to current or subsequent license
periods
● service as member of State Legislature substitutes for 15 hours of course work
● licensees licensed for less than 1 year and applying for first renewal are not
required to complete the 15 hours of continuing education for that renewal period
● licensees 65 years old on or before September 30, 2000 who have held license for
10 years are not required to complete continuing education

● reciprocal licensees holding Alabama license for less than 1 year and renewing for
first time are not required to complete continuing education for that renewal; this
exemption only applies to reciprocal licenses received after September 30, 2015
Reciprocal license ● an Alabama reciprocal license may be obtained by current licensees from another
qualifying state
● a qualifying state is one where the licensee completed pre-license course work and
passed the national and state law portions of the license exam
● reciprocal license applicants must provide certificate of licensure from the other
state issued within preceding 120 days and dated no later than June 1
● applicant must complete 6 hours of AREC-approved course work in Alabama real
estate and pass written exam on Alabama real estate with score of 70% within 6
months of completing the 6 hours of course work
● failure to meet the deadline results in applicant needing to again complete the
course work
● reciprocal license applicant must submit application, licensure fees, and Recovery
Fund fees
● reciprocal license salesperson licensee must apply for salesperson license;
reciprocal license broker licensee must apply for broker license
● after reciprocal licensure, licensee must complete Alabama 15 hour continuing
education requirements or show proof other state license is still active
● must take Alabama Risk Management course and electives from another state
Co-brokering ● nonresident principal broker licensed in other state can sign agreement with
Alabama qualifying broker to conduct real estate transactions in Alabama.
● AL broker must confirm the nonresident's principal broker license in the other
state
• nonresident broker is limited to three transactions (with a transaction including
multiple properties from the same portfolio) up to $50 million per calendar year.
● the agreement must be filed with AREC within 10 days of signing
● AL broker must have listing or joint listing that specifies all material terms,
including financial terms, and supervise property showings
● earnest money to be held in Alabama unless client agrees otherwise
● nonresident broker agrees to civil action against him/her resulting from claim
• the regulatory body overseeing the nonresident broker will be notified if any
complaints are filed against that broker.
● nonresident broker agrees to abide by AL laws and rules
● AL broker is liable for nonresident broker's actions
LICENSE STATUS ● Alabama real estate licenses can be active, inactive, expired, or lapsed
● active status allows the licensee to practice real estate
● inactive status is still valid but restricts the licensee from practicing real estate
● expired occurs when the license has not been renewed by the deadline; the license
is on inactive status when expired
● lapsed licenses have not been renewed within 12 months of the renewal deadline
and may not be renewed once lapsed
Definition of a licensee ● per AL law, a licensee is any real estate broker, salesperson, or company licensed
under AL license law
● salespersons must work under the supervision of a qualifying broker
● brokers are either associate brokers or qualifying brokers
● a company is a sole proprietorship, corporation, partnership, branch office, or
lawfully constituted business organization licensed under AL license law

Transfer of license ● licensees are registered under a specific real estate office and qualifying broker but
may want to work for a different qualifying broker
● the licensee must give notice to AREC and the current qualifying broker of his or
her intent to transfer to another qualifying broker
● the licensee must pay a transfer fee
● the new qualifying broker must file a transfer request with AREC with a statement
assuming liability for the licensee
● a company must pay a transfer fee for each license containing the current and new
qualifying brokers' names and for each branch office
● the transferring licensee must mail the license to AREC by certified or registered
mail with receipt
● documents and fees must be submitted to AREC within 10 days of receipt of
intent to transfer; AREC will then issue new license under the new qualifying
broker
● documents and fees not submitted within the 10 days voids the transfer and results
in the current qualifying broker retaining responsibility for the licensee
Evidence of transfer ● the mail receipt obtained when the transfer documents are sent to AREC serves as
evidence of the transfer
Definition of inactive
license ● an inactive license is one that restricts the licensee from legally performing real
estate activities that require a license
● a license is inactive when it is held by AREC due to a legal action, an AREC
order, or the licensee's request
● a license is also inactive when it is still renewable but has not been renewed by the
deadline
● a license is inactive during second 6 months of temporary licensure if post-license
education has not been completed
● the license must be activated for licensee to legally engage in real estate activities
Recovery Fund fee
exemption ● licenses issued on inactive status are not charged a Recovery Fund fee until the
license is activated
● any supplemental Recovery Fund fees must also be paid prior to activating the
license
Reactivation of inactive
license ● the licensee must apply to AREC and pay the fee to activate an inactive license
● the licensee must have completed 15 hours of continuing education for the current
license period prior to reactivation
● the licensee must complete an additional 15 hours of continuing education for
license renewal for the next license period
Return of license ● a corporation, partnership, or individually owned company can return the license
of a licensee they wish to stop doing business in the company's name
● the company must notify AREC and the licensee in writing
